repnme.cdata!:
Venezuela - Caracas Metropolitan Health
            Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Caracas Metropolitan
            Health Services Project for Venezuela were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; the risk to
            development outcome was satisfactory; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and the Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: An
            adequate political climate is crucial for project success
            when there are many actors involved, particularly in a
            decentralization process. Although the project had a good
            start mobilizing resources and support from the
            municipalities involved in developing a decentralized
            system, further steps for implementing it were stalled by a
            mix of different approaches to resource allocations, but
            most importantly by the political climate that took place in
            Venezuela during most of the 2002-04 period. Different
            positions on how to implement a decentralized program became
            insurmountable and the project suffered from this struggle,
            leading to a sizable reduction in project scope. Although
            the participation of many political actors was acknowledged
            during appraisal as an important risk factor, it was not
            possible to have foreseen that. The political environment
            will make it impossible to implement a decentralized scheme
            as originally conceived. When supporting a decentralization
            process, project implementation is best placed as low as
            possible within the available institutional structure.

repnme.cdata!:
Venezuela - Caracas Metropolitan Health
            Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Caracas Metropolitan Health Services
            Project seeks to: a) expand the access to and improve the
            quality and efficiency of ambulatory care services,
            pre-medical emergency medical services, and outpatient
            services of hospitals, for 2.4 million vulnerable persons
            living in selected municipalities and parishes of the
            Metropolitan District of Caracas (MDC); b) improve the
            management of the health care system and support the
            decentralization process in the health system of the MDC;
            and c) develop HIV/AIDS prevention and control strategies
            and activities in the MDC. There are five project
            components. 1) This component will support the strengthening
            of health care networks in the MDC to facilitate access,
            expand coverage, and improve the quality of health services
            in selected parishes and municipalities. 2) The
            institutional development component will ensure the virtual
            integration of health facilities into networks and efficient
            and effective delivery of the comprehensive health care
            program. 3) This component will finance development of
            strategies and activities for HIV/AIDS prevention and
            control in MDC. 4) This component will finance technical
            assistance and activities to support the development of
            legal and organizational instruments and models in MDC. 5)
            The component will support project management, monitoring,
            supervision, and impact evaluation of the project.
